final_report.root_cause: compose-post-service misconfiguration in service discovery/endpoints caused downstream Thrift calls to be resolved/routed back to compose-post-service, producing re-entrant RPC loops (compose-post -> other service -> compose-post ...). At the same time post-storage-service was refusing connections and compose-post-service performed aggressive, sub-second retries (no effective backoff), producing tight retry storms that amplified load, errors and latency. A secondary contributing configuration issue is that text-service's Kubernetes Service exposes only an unnamed numeric port (9090) while compose-post likely expects a named Thrift port, causing partial RPC failures and additional retries, but the epicenter of the incident is compose-post-service's misrouting + retry behavior.
final_report.evidence_summary: 1) Multiple distributed traces (traceIDs: 0220992b34c261cc, 00d29c18dfd27759, 01aaa932ec712675, 00bf85828e7386e6, 01d97f64e9609a36, 01b483546105920a, 0248771e702c1d05) show compose-post-service appearing repeatedly in the same trace sequence (e.g. nginx-thrift -> compose-post-service -> text-service -> compose-post-service...), demonstrating re-entrant/looping RPCs rather than linear fan-out. All these traces have has_error=true. 2) compose-post-service logs contain many repeated Thrift client connection failures: 'TSocket::open() connect() <Host: post-storage-service Port: 9090>: Connection refused' and repeated '[ClientPool.h:114:Pop] Failed to connect post-storage-client' entries at sub-second intervals, showing aggressive retry behavior toward post-storage-service. 3) kubectl_describe(Service text-service) shows the Service exposes only a numeric port 9090 with no port name; compose-post's configured downstream dependencies include text-service, suggesting a port/port-name mismatch that can cause partial RPC failures. 4) Traces also show repeated alternation among text-service, url-shorten-service and user-mention-service consistent with caller-side retries or duplicated invocations.
final_report.investigation_summary: Priority weighting and actions: Priority #1 investigation (completed) focused on the epicenter and confirmed compose-post-service as the source of reentrant RPC loops by correlating traces and compose-post logs (repeated self-appearance in traces plus repeated Thrift connection refused and client-pool failures). Priority #2 investigation (completed) performed two-sided checks for compose-post -> text-service and found a Service port naming mismatch: text-service exposes only an unnamed numeric port 9090 while compose-post declares text-service as a dependency (likely expecting a named Thrift port). Additional planned tasks (priorities 3-8) targeted deeper two-sided checks for user-service, url-shorten, caches and DBs; these produced supporting hypotheses (e.g., url-shorten and text-service interactions) but were not required to localize the epicenter. Overall conclusion: the incident was caused primarily by compose-post-service misrouting/service-discovery misconfiguration that led to re-entrant RPC loops, amplified by aggressive retry behavior against an unreachable post-storage-service. The unnamed port on text-service is a contributing configuration issue that increased failure rates and retries.
